description: From Middle French incommensurable, from Medieval Latin incommensurabilis.
Its full etymology is equivalent to that of in- + commensurable.

adjectives.description: incommensurable (comparative more incommensurable, superlative most incommensurable)

entries.meaning: (mathematics, of two real numbers) having a ratio that is not expressible as a fraction of two integers.
examples: The side and diagonal of a square are incommensurable with each other; the diameter and circumference of a circle are incommensurable.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, of two integers) having no common integer divisor except 1.
Not able to be measured by the same standards as another term in the context.
An incommensurable value or quantity; an irrational number.
examples: Unfortunately for Pythagoras, his theorem led at once to the discovery of incommensurables, which appeared to disprove his whole philosophy.
